person.note: In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read ابشمر. This is not exactly the same name.
The inscription includes an allusion to מרהמו אלן בעל שמין וארדן ... שעבהמו ישראל (their Master God Lord of Heaven and earth … and his folk Israel).
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Ḥimyarite kingdom, see Introduction 8.3.3.

state.note: Deed of sale inscription, Ḥaṣi, Yemen

person.note: In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19.
The inscription describes sale of territory to Jews, but it is not certain that the seller is Jewish too.
See Introduction 8.3.3.
In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read اسار. On the additional א as vowel, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3.1, p. 13.
This is Joseph (36) B/M, in vol. 4, p. 89.
On the Jewishness of this dynasty see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel.”
Was king of Ḥimyar in these dates, see Introduction 8.3.3.

state.note: Ḏāra’mar (1), brother of the king of Ḥimyar

person.note: In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read ايمان. On the additional א as vowel, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3.1, p. 13.
He is the brother of Abi-Karib (1) Tiban (1) Asa‘d (1) of vol. 4, pp. 295, 263, 259 (all under A/M), see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel,” p. 897. I have not seen the inscriptions, see Introduction 8.3.
On the Jewishness of this dynasty see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel.”
Was never a king of Ḥimyar himself. These are the dates of his brother’s reign, see Introduction 8.3.3.
In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read نالن. On the interchange of the sound ‘m’ and ‘n’ see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.3, p. 29.
The inscription includes an allusion to מרהמו אלן בעל שמין וארדן ... שעבהמו ישראל (their Master God Lord of Heaven and earth … and their folk Israel).
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Ḥimyarite kingdom, see Introduction 8.3.3.
In inscriptions in Sabbaitic script. I have not seen the inscriptions, see Introduction 8.3.
He is the son of Abi-Karib (1) Tiban (1) Asa‘d (1) of vol. 4, pp. 295, 263, 259, see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel,” p. 897 and Introduction 8.3.
The inscriptions have no specific indication of Jewishness. On the Jewishness of this dynasty see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel.”
His fatherwas king of Ḥimyar in these dates, see Introduction 8.3.3.

In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read حرين. On the interchange of the sound ‘m’ and ‘n’ see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.3, p. 29. The word בנו (بنو) is usually employed in ancient Arabic literature to represent a clan or a tribe, see the various Jewish tribes so desigantd, listed in vol. 4, Introduction 6.1.1.1, pp. 29-30 and 6.1.3.3, p. 31. What it is doing here is unclear.
The inscription includes an allusion to מרהמו אלן בעל שמין וארדן ... שעבהמו ישראל (their Master God Lord of Heaven and earth … and their folk Israel).
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Ḥimyarite kingdom, see Introduction 8.3.3.
In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read حسان. On the additional א as vowel, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13.
He is the son of Abi-Karib (1) Tiban (1) Asa‘d (1) of vol. 4, pp. 295, 263, 259, see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel,” p. 897 and Introduction 8.3.
On the Jewishness of this dynasty see Robin, “Ḥimyar et Israel.”
Was king of Ḥimyar in these dates, see Introduction 8.3.3.

state.note: Of Ṣaḥat, leader of the tribes Madhi and Safar
Deed of sale inscription, Ḥaṣi, Yemen

person.note: In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read اشرق. On the ا as an abbreviation of the ال prefix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3, p. 13.
In Sabbaic – דצחת, קיל שעבניהין מדחי וספר.
The inscription describes sale of territory to Jews, but it is not certain that the seller is Jewish too, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.4.1, p. 30.

In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read قشادن. On this suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3, p. 27. On the ا vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3.1, p. 13.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.9.1, p. 53.
See Introduction 8.3.3.

state.note: Deed of sale inscription, Ḥaṣi, Yemen

person.note: In the Sabbaic script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 19. In Arabic this would read يقعموت. The י is probably a prefix typical in Ḥimyarite Arabic, see below at the other names starting with ي recorded in this file. On the و as vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, p. 13.
In Sabbaic – דספר.
The inscription describes sale of territory to Jews, but it is not certain that the seller is Jewish too.
